title: 111_hr6570
content: The Act titled "Respect for Rights of Conscience Act of 2010" is cited as the short title. The findings and purposes of the Act are outlined in section 2. Congress finds that the protection of rights of conscience against civil authority is a fundamental principle deeply rooted in the history and laws of the United States, including healthcare laws. The Federal Government had not imposed coverage or care requirements infringing on conscience rights until the enactment of the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act. PPACA mandates health plans to cover essential health benefits and preventive services, including services for women. It allows exemptions for some religious groups but does not permit objections to specific services based on religious or moral grounds. The PPACA mandates health plans to cover essential health benefits and preventive services, including services for women. However, objections to specific items or services based on religious or moral grounds are not allowed, jeopardizing individuals' rights of conscience and ability to participate freely in the health insurance marketplace. The Act aims to ensure that health care stakeholders can access coverage consistent with their religious beliefs and moral convictions without fear of discrimination. The PPACA aims to prevent exclusion of individuals with conscientious objections from health plans or programs under the Act. The PPACA aims to prevent exclusion of individuals with conscientious objections from health plans or programs under the Act. SEC. 3. RESPECT FOR RIGHTS OF CONSCIENCE. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amends Section 1302(b) to protect the rights of conscience regarding specific items or services in health plans. This ensures that health plans cannot be penalized for not covering certain items or services based on conscientious objections. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amends Section 1302(b) to protect conscience rights for health plans. It allows for exemptions if coverage goes against religious beliefs or moral convictions of the sponsor, issuer, or beneficiary. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amends Section 1302(b) to protect conscience rights for health plans, allowing exemptions for providers with religious or moral objections. Providers cannot be required to offer, participate in, or refer for services against their beliefs. No Exchange or governmental entity can discriminate against providers exercising their rights of conscience. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amends Section 1302(b) to protect conscience rights for health plans, allowing exemptions for providers with religious or moral objections. Providers cannot be required to offer, participate in, or refer for services against their beliefs. No discrimination is allowed against those who choose not to provide specific items or services based on conscience rights. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act amends Section 1302(b) to protect conscience rights for health plans, allowing exemptions for providers with religious or moral objections. Individuals or entities can assert a violation of this paragraph in a judicial proceeding, with Federal courts having jurisdiction to provide legal or equitable relief for violations, including injunctive relief, damages, and attorney fees. The paragraph allows the Attorney General or any party with standing to complain of a violation to seek interim relief through a court order. The Office for Civil Rights of the Department of Health and Human Services is designated to receive complaints of discrimination based on this paragraph and coordinate the investigation of such complaints. The Secretary may issue regulations to ensure that health plans excluding specific items or services have an actuarial value equivalent to plans that do not exclude them. The amendment made by subsection (a) regarding coverage that does not exclude certain items or services will be effective as if included in the enactment of Public Law 111-148.
